items.synopsis: Follow our live blog for the latest news in the lead-up to voting in the referendum on October 14.

title.children: Albanese says more than 600,000 people have voted early in Voice referendum

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By political reporter Dana Morse The Australian Electoral Commission has reaffirmed its neutral stance on the Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum, after No campaigner Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price suggested the organisation is favouring the Yes vote. On the campaign trail in the swing state of South Australia, Senator Nampijinpa Price made accusations about the actions of the electoral commission. "It does very much seem that there is more favour towards Yes side than the No side and that is very much a concern," she said. The AEC has defended itself in a statement, saying the organisation has always been, and remains neutral, and that the electoral commission is administering the referendum process in the same manner as federal elections.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Electoral commission responds to claims one side of the Voice is being favoured

children.content: By political reporter Dana Morse
The
Australian Electoral Commission
has reaffirmed its neutral stance on the
Indigenous Voice to Parliament
referendum, after No campaigner
Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price
suggested the organisation is favouring the Yes vote.
On the campaign trail in the swing state of South Australia,
Senator Nampijinpa Price
made accusations about the actions of the electoral commission.
"It does very much seem that there is more favour towards Yes side than the No side and that is very much a concern," she said.

The AEC has defended itself in a statement, saying the organisation has always been, and remains neutral, and that the electoral commission is administering the referendum process in the same manner as federal elections.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Isabella Higgins The Yes campaign is focusing on attracting votes from Australia's many multi-cultural communities, with a number of events planned in the coming days. "Misinformation is rife," said well known Indigenous leader and co-architect of the Uluru statement, Noel Pearson. He was campaigning in Sydney’s inner-west at the Addi Road Food Bank with 2023 Local Hero of the Year and founder of Turbans 4 Australia, Amar Singh. "We're working very hard to overcome the misinformation that the no campaign is throwing at all communities in the country, not the least the multicultural community,” Mr Pearson said. “We've done a heap of events with people in western Sydney here with English as a second language communities." During the event he briefly broke into song, using lyrics he says were written by “Aunty Dora” in his home community. "What of the first peoples unrecognised and unseen voices of wisdom silenced from the start, erased from history?" he sang, to the gathered group. Mr Pearson called on “the Italian,” “the Greeks,” “the Eastern Europeans,” and the “western Europeans,” who “built this country” and “built great lives here for your families”. “Extend the hand of opportunity to the original peoples of this country.” Mr Singh has travelled around the country promoting the Voice to Parliament to diverse communities because he believes it'll make "a better, more diverse Australia".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Noel Pearson says misinformation is ‘rife’ in multi-cultural communities

props.alt: Noel Person stands in front of microphones wearing a shirt that says Yes.

children.content: Indigenous leader and co-architect of the Uluru statement Noel Pearson.
(ABC News: Isabella Higgins)

Mr Pearson called on “the Italian,” “the Greeks,” “the Eastern Europeans,” and the “western Europeans,” who “built this country” and “built great lives here for your families”.
“Extend the hand of opportunity to the original peoples of this country.”
Mr Singh has travelled around the country promoting the Voice to Parliament to diverse communities because he believes it'll make "a better, more diverse Australia".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Indigenous mental health professionals say there has been an up tick in First Nations Australians accessing support services in the lead up to the Voice to Parliament referendum. A national crisis support line reported a 108 per cent increase in callers experiencing abuse, racism and trauma. Dr Tracy Westerman is a Nyamal woman from Indigenous Psychological Services, and says many of her clients are being forced to take on more cultural load. "A lot of it is basically that conversations are just happening everywhere and Aboriginal people are now being forced to take on conversations in public, conversations in families and obviously these conversations aren't just small ones." Support for Indigenous Australians: Aboriginal & Torres Strait Islander crisis support line 13YARN on 139276 eSafety Commission's First Nation resources
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Psychologist says First Nations people are taking on more culture load ahead of Voice vote

children.content: Indigenous mental health professionals say there has been an up tick in First Nations Australians accessing support services in the lead up to the Voice to Parliament referendum.
A national crisis support line reported a 108 per cent increase in callers experiencing abuse, racism and trauma.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Why has the Aussie dollar been sliding against the greenback? NAB's senior foreign exchange analyst Rodrigo Catril joins the program. We ask ANZ's chief economist Richard Yetsenga if the markets are misreading China's economic troubles. And Emily Stewart meets consumers who have turned to grocery shopping online as cost of living pressures bite. Watch ABC News at 8:44pm, after the late news on ABC TV, and anytime on ABC iView.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Coming up on The Business tonight

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reuters has a little report that Australian billionaire Gina Rinehart has increased her stake in Liontown Resources again. Rinehart's company Hancock Prospecting let the ASX know yesterday evening that it has recently increased its stake in Liontown to 14.67%, from 12.36%. It will give Hancock a greater say over Liontown's direction as it awaits a takeover offer from Ablemarle, the world's biggest lithium producer. And when you look back through the company filings, you'll find Ms Rinehart has been increasing her stake in Liontown quite quickly. Less than four weeks ago, the Hancock group owned 7.72% voting power, but that was increased to 10.69% two weeks later, then to 12.36%, and now to 14.67%. Liontown shares have risen 0.5% today to $2.97 per share, up around 120% this year. The graph below shows how its share price has performed over the last six months:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Gina Rinehart increases stake in lithium developer Liontown Resources

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A little earlier today New Zealand's central bank kept its cash rate on hold at 5.5%, with the bank saying past rate hikes have tempered inflation. The RBNZ decision leaves the cash rate at its 15-year high for a third straight meeting. "Interest rates are constraining economic activity and reducing inflationary pressure as required," the central bank said in a statement. The RBNZ said the monetary committee agreed that interest rates will need to remain at a restrictive level for the foreseeable future to ensure consumer price inflation returns to its 1% to 3% target range. "With monetary conditions remaining restrictive, spending growth is expected to decline further," the bank said. However, like the RBA, it cautioned of potential future increases to rates should inflation not slow as much as required.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Reserve Bank of New Zealand leaves rates on hold at 5.5pc

The RBNZ decision leaves the cash rate at its 15-year high for a third straight meeting.
"Interest rates are constraining economic activity and reducing inflationary pressure as required," the central bank said in a statement.
The RBNZ said the monetary committee agreed that
interest rates will need to remain at a restrictive level for the foreseeable future
to ensure consumer price inflation returns to its 1% to 3% target range.
"With monetary conditions remaining restrictive, spending growth is expected to decline further," the bank said.
However, like the RBA, it cautioned of
potential future increases to rates
should inflation not slow as much as required.
